Mediation

You can use the help of a mediator if you can’t agree on some issues. Mediators won’t take sides or give you legal advice but will show all the options available to you.

Using a mediator is quicker, cheaper and less stressful than going to court.

Find out more about mediation

 

Benefits:

  • 4 times quicker and 5 times cheaper than going to court
  • less stressful, with less conflict between you and your partner
  • gives you more control - if you go to court a judge makes the decision
  • easier on your children and helps them continue important family relationships
  • improves communication with your ex-partner

The average cost of a mediation session is £80. Most people need between 1 and 2 sessions. If you don’t work, or are on a low income, you may be able to get legal aid

Duration:

Each session lasts approximately 90 minutes.

Is this for you

Mediation works for most people - two thirds of couples who attend reach an agreement.

You must first meet with a mediator to check if it’s right for you. This is called a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM). The average cost of a MIAM is £30.

Agreements made in mediation aren’t legally binding although you can hire a solicitor to check your new arrangements
